But if you're talking about cloning a full fledged person, than I don't see much point. Efforts to clone oneself as a form of "immortality" are just silly; your clone will not be you.  Nope, that wouldn't work. Normally, when a new disease shows up, only a few will die from it right away; those most susceptible. The rest will sicken to a greater or lesser degree, and if they're going to die it will take long enough that you might have time to find a cure first. But if your whole herd is genetically identical, than they will all have the exact same susceptibility to a new disease. That means it won't just be a few of the herd that gets hit hard. If any get really sick they all will, and if any are going to die quickly, they all will. By the time you know you have a problem, your herd would be gone.

 Actually bananas are a great example of my point. Bananas are, as you say, basically clones. There are a handful of strains out there. The bananas we eat today are not the bananas our parents ate. 30 some years ago there was one popular strain, and everyone grew that one. Then some blight showed up, and before anyone could do anything about it pretty much the entire banana crop was gone. The blight was particularly effective against that one strain, and wiped it out. The bananas we have today are from a different strain, one that wasn't as susceptible to that one disease.
